importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, a significant milestone in the country's space programme.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of the launch and deployment in 2025 reflects Pakistan's recent push to expand its space capabilities, including launching three satellites in the same year.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, into orbit from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
The satellite is developed by SUPARCO, Pakistan’s national space agency, and marks a major step forward in Pakistan’s space programme.

Hyperspectral technology allows the satellite to detect subtle chemical or material changes on the ground, enabling applications in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
The data from H1 is expected to improve agricultural productivity, enhance climate resilience, and support better management of natural resources.

The satellite's capabilities are particularly relevant to Pakistan’s development goals, including those under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where accurate geohazard assessments are vital.
The launch reflects and strengthens the strategic partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.
Two other satellites, EO-1 and KS-1, are already fully operational in orbit, indicating a growing momentum in Pakistan’s space capabilities.
It will take approximately two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is the central technological achievement of the article, enabling detailed analysis of land use, agriculture, and environmental conditions.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral satellite’s ability to monitor geohazards supports infrastructure development and safety within CPEC, enhancing project resilience.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is quoted as stating the potential of the satellite to revolutionize agriculture and resource management, giving a direct voice to the mission’s benefits.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The foreign affairs department of Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ministry highlighted the strategic partnership with China and the broader national development impact of the satellite launch.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major advancement in its space programme. Developed by SUPARCO, the satellite uses hyperspectral technology to detect subtle ground-based material changes, enabling improved monitoring of agriculture, water resources, urban planning, and disaster risks. The launch is a key component of Pakistan’s broader space initiative, which includes three operational satellites (EO-1 and KS-1), and is especially relevant to national development goals such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where accurate geohazard assessments are crucial. The mission underscores the strategic partnership between Pakistan and China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation, and although full operationality of H1 will take about two months, it is expected to significantly enhance national capabilities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, and climate resilience.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
